perturbation.original_text: During the period beginning on the Effective Date and ending on December 31, 2018 (the “Development Term”), each Party (the “Offering Party”) agrees to provide to the other Party (the “Receiving Party”) a right of first offer with respect to any proposed offer or arrangement, which the Offering Party (or its affiliate) desires to accept, under which the Offering Party or one of its affiliates would acquire the ownership of real property in the Market Area (the “Development Property”) on which a Hyatt All-Inclusive Resort would operate (a “Development Opportunity”).
perturbation.changed_text: During the period beginning on the Effective Date and ending on December 31, 2018 (the “Development Term”), each Party (the “Offering Party”) will consider providing to the other Party (the “Receiving Party”) a right of first offer with respect to any proposed offer or arrangement, which the Offering Party (or its affiliate) desires to accept, under which the Offering Party or one of its affiliates would acquire the ownership of real property in the Market Area (the “Development Property”) on which a Hyatt All-Inclusive Resort would operate (a “Development Opportunity”).
perturbation.explanation: The original text states that each party *agrees* to provide the right of first offer. The modified text changes "agrees to provide" to "will consider providing," introducing uncertainty and contradicting the original obligation. This creates ambiguity as to whether the right of first offer is mandatory or discretionary.

perturbation.original_text: Any required notice shall be effective two business days after it is sent by a recognized international courier service to the address of the other Party stated in this Agreement, or such other address as shall be notified to the other Party in writing, and any receipt issued by the courier service shall be conclusive evidence of the fact and date of sending of any such notice.
perturbation.changed_text: Any required notice may be deemed effective at the discretion of the receiving party; otherwise, it shall be effective ten business days after it is sent by a recognized international courier service to the address of the other Party stated in this Agreement, or such other address as shall be notified to the other Party in writing, and any receipt issued by the courier service shall be evidence, though not conclusive, of the fact and date of sending of any such notice.
perturbation.explanation: The original clause states that notice is *effective* two business days after sending via courier, and that the courier receipt is *conclusive* evidence. The modified version introduces subjectivity by stating effectiveness of notice is up to the receipient, and that the receipt is *not conclusive* evidence. This contradicts the original, making the effectiveness of notice and the validity of proof of sending ambiguous.

perturbation.original_text: All disputes arising out of or in connection with this Agreement shall to the extent possible be settled amicably by negotiation between the Parties within fifteen (15) days from the date of written notice by either Party of the existence of such dispute, and, failing such amicable settlement, shall be finally settled by arbitration under the Rules of Arbitration of the International Chamber of Commerce (“Rules”).
perturbation.changed_text: All disputes arising out of or in connection with this Agreement may, at the discretion of both parties, be settled amicably by negotiation between the Parties within fifteen (15) days from the date of written notice by either Party of the existence of such dispute, and, failing such amicable settlement, may be settled by arbitration under the local court system instead of the Rules of Arbitration of the International Chamber of Commerce (“Rules”).
perturbation.explanation: The original text mandates that disputes *shall* be settled by negotiation and then *shall* be finally settled by arbitration. The modified version introduces optionality, stating that disputes *may* be settled amicably at the discretion of both parties and *may* be settled locally instead of the ICC, and introduces uncertainty. This contradicts the original mandatory dispute resolution process.
